name: NPR
text:
Avery Hoppa is still working, so she's trying to support local businesses. 

But, she says, "if I'm buying things ... that store has to be open and possibly it's putting those people at risk."

"It's just hard to figure out. What's the right thing to do?" https://t.co/7eMmADbYKQ

name: NPR
text:
The Boston Marathon has been canceled for the first time in its 124-year history.

All participants who were set to run in the event will be eligible to participate in an online alternative.
https://t.co/UzjALVYZFV

name: NPR
text:
Mike Pence’s chief of staff owns as much as $1.6 million worth of stocks in companies linked to coronavirus response.

He declared some to be possible conflicts of interest but hasn't divested from them.

"This is now a red alarm," said an ethics watchdog. https://t.co/95BrXEoZUq

name: NPR
text:
We love seeing new faces in the Tiny Desk Contest each year — but it's exciting to recognize the artists who come back time after time, giving us a little view into their growth as musicians. 

Here's a playlist of our favorite returning artists👇 https://t.co/udKYcg0nID

name: NPR
text:
Taking "slow and low" breaths through the nose can help relieve stress and reduce blood pressure, notes journalist James Nestor. 

"When we breathe through our mouths, we're denying our bodies the ability to do this." 
https://t.co/Yr8cwesOTI

name: NPR
text:
Outrage. Grief. Frustration. 

Here are scenes from the protests in Minneapolis and Los Angeles following George Floyd's death.
https://t.co/yNHUro5G41

name: NPR
text:
We're tracking coronavirus restrictions in every state — and the steps officials are taking to reopen their communities.

West: https://t.co/uwwcrPfbxE
Midwest: https://t.co/HYwvxh4tpT
South: https://t.co/EfozD9gnCM
Northeast: https://t.co/NeZOT4m2qU

https://t.co/MIPhn7aSkj

name: NPR
text:
NEW: The National Guard confirmed it is deploying more than 500 soldiers to Minneapolis, St. Paul and surrounding areas, adding "a key objective is to ensure fire departments are able to respond to calls."
https://t.co/TEWKKmiMPs

name: NPR
text: Local and federal officials are growing increasingly concerned about Fourth of July events on the National Mall. President Trump has made no indication he plans to cancel the annual celebration. @wamu885 https://t.co/F58kZ1jXr8

name: NPR
text: Questlove isn't letting a pandemic slow him down. The Roots drummer, DJ and cookbook author is adding one more thing to his resume — virtual potluck dinner host. https://t.co/oGYUy2YS8K

name: NPR
text: JUST IN: Flames are ravaging the Third Precinct police building in Minneapolis, which has been a focal point of demonstrations over George Floyd's death. A police spokesperson says personnel there are safe. https://t.co/z4mujsI9Bo

name: NPR
text:
New Yorkers Gali Beeri and Joshua Boliver met in March as the city was about to lock down. 

Then the near-strangers took a leap of faith to ride out quarantine in Joshua's apartment.
https://t.co/JAQlmQLHGF

name: NPR
text: We’re answering your questions about the process to get a vaccine for the coronavirus, workplace safety and voter registration amid the pandemic. 👇https://t.co/51udRCNR7W

name: NPR
text: A lot of county and state fairs have been canceled because of the new coronavirus, but some Californians jonesing for fair food were able to get their fix with special drive-through to-go meals -- including funnel cake fries. @CapRadioNews https://t.co/vS356BKQLt

name: NPR
text:
Mike Pence’s chief of staff owns stocks in at least 23 companies doing work linked to the White House pandemic response.

On at least two recent occasions during his work on the coronavirus task force, he has mentioned companies in which he holds stock.
https://t.co/N9g95wchCw

name: NPR
text:
Illinois is reopening some retail shops, restaurants, salons and other businesses Friday. But Chicago is delaying its limited business reopening until June 3, Mayor Lori Lightfoot said.
https://t.co/BPD2P0r3IL

name: NPR
text:
Yemen already suffers what the U.N. calls the world's most extreme humanitarian crisis. 

As the virus spreads, healthcare facilities lack everything from PPE for staff to beds for the ill to specialist expertise.
https://t.co/NwPAb8mP7Y

name: NPR
text: Amazon hired 175,000 temporary workers to deal with the online shopping spike. Now it's offering to convert 125,000 into permanent full-time employees. https://t.co/XcU1gozq5s

name: NPR
text:
Rhiannon Giddens and her partner, Francesco Turrisi, are hoping to offer us some comfort with down-home tunes in this Tiny Desk (home) concert. 

And with banjos, fiddles, a bodhrán, and that stunning voice, it works.
https://t.co/it5MYMmDBS

name: NPR
text:
The army has been "tactically dispersing" as the world socially distanced. But they'll need more testing if they want to run important defense drills safely — and they're not alone.

Everyone — governor or mayor or even a general — wants more supplies. https://t.co/6xgjEsWe6i

name: NPR
text:
The President tweeted about shooting protestors in Minneapolis.

Twitter said the tweet glorified violence — and hid it from view. https://t.co/UYNRIu5f5D

name: NPR
text:
Latinos are set to be the largest minority voting group in November, as well as crucial electorates in battleground states. 

So if Joe Biden wants to spur these key votes, he may want to learn a thing or two from Bernie Sander's campaign, experts say. https://t.co/1Djdh42iwF

name: NPR
text: Federal prosecutors will appeal for a retrial over a 2014 armed standoff between Cliven Bundy, his militia and federal agents who had come to round up the rancher's cows that were illegally grazing on federal land. https://t.co/rSK9CTFlu2

name: NPR
text:
Live in Texas and want to vote by mail because of the pandemic? You can, as long as:

🗳You're over 65 or disabled 
🗳Live outside your registered county
🗳You're in jail — but not convicted

Otherwise, you may be prosecuted for voter fraud. https://t.co/FR7o9nW3jj

name: NPR
text:
This month, the IRS announced that it would let employees add, drop or alter some of their employee health care benefits for the remainder of 2020. 

But there's a catch: Your employer has to allow the changes. https://t.co/62pKLGaZmo

name: NPR
text:
Seven people were shot, leaving at least one in critical condition, during a protest in downtown Louisville over the death of Breonna Taylor. @WFPLNews 
https://t.co/p1QMn9kLKT

name: NPR
text: “A black reporter from CNN was arrested while legally covering the protests in Minneapolis,” the network noted, ref… https://t.co/lnmFXtBhFk

name: NPR
text:
Wearing a mask has become a political statement — at times a clear divide between Democrat and Republican. 

But public health and elected officials are trying to remind people that wearing a mask is "common sense" to protect yourself and others.  https://t.co/8k0s43Eue0

name: NPR
text:
@NPR  State police arrested the CNN crew — consisting of correspondent Omar Jimenez, producer Bill Kirkos and photojournalist Leonel Mendez — while they were reporting about the unrest on live TV. 

They were released about an hour later. https://t.co/afJgcN3OR7

name: NPR
text:
Brazil has over 438,238 COVID-19 cases — the second-highest globally — and daily death counts are still rising.

But governors are easing social distancing restrictions across the country, even as medical researchers warn infections haven't peaked. https://t.co/19dZ1TELmw

name: NPR
text:
The protests calling for justice for Breonna Taylor started peacefully. But shortly after 11:30 p.m., shots were fired. It's not yet clear by whom.
https://t.co/wPKziT5POT

name: NPR
text:
New Zealand is now down to only one active COVID-19 case. The last time a new case was reported in the country was over a week ago. 

No one is currently hospitalized with the disease. https://t.co/xPTUybdy96

name: NPR
text:
Beijing is moving to impose a national security law in Hong Kong. Here's the breakdown:

• The legality of this power grab is unclear
• Beijing’s impact might not be limited
• There's some local support 
• China’s security forces will likely enforce it https://t.co/qfXytkSH1F

name: NPR
text:
Opinion:

 "As public health experts who have worked extensively on global health issues, we've been struck by how this neocolonialist attitude has played out in this unprecedented pandemic," write @AbraarKaran and @DrMishalK.
https://t.co/T2er1LzsVh

name: NPR
text:
As an essential supermarket employee, Yesenia Ortiz has been accused of violating quarantine as she leaves for work, risking her health for low pay.

But she doesn't get mad — instead, she buys groceries for those who ask where she's going. https://t.co/LBCXxd4DOx

name: NPR
text: JUST IN: Derek Chauvin — the officer who was filmed with his knee on George Floyd's neck as he begged for his life… https://t.co/dGf7m6kZnP

name: NPR
text:
Barack Obama says he shares the “anguish” that many feel about George Floyd. 

Read his full statement, including a reference to a viral video of a song by Keedron Bryant, who pleads, “I just want to live, God protect me.” https://t.co/0ghn0e71Up

name: NPR
text: @NPR The former Minneapolis police officer planted a knee on George Floyd's neck for at least seven minutes as Floyd cried for help and eventually fell silent, while bystanders shouted that he was dying. https://t.co/6QthLJKFqM

name: NPR
text:
Dr. Ming Lin was fired after critiquing his hospital's response to the coronavirus pandemic. Now he's suing. 

"This is about people on the front line being given the opportunity to speak out without being terminated and being reprimanded," he says. https://t.co/dCmTPEDV6G

name: NPR
text: Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz has issued an apology for the arrests of the CNN crew. https://t.co/QzgpeIHvi9

name: NPR
text:
Two weeks ago the CDC published a report calling choir practice "a superspreading event" for coronavirus.

But their guidance on limiting choirs at religious services disappeared over the weekend, apparently because the White House hadn't approved it. https://t.co/eZDzzs5uZC

name: NPR
text:
Former Vice President Joe Biden believes the killing of George Floyd should be a reckoning for the nation, saying "With our complacency, our silence, we are complicit in perpetuating these cycles of violence.”
https://t.co/6FmrIQGD6L

name: NPR
text:
NEW: Minneapolis Mayor Jacob Frey has ordered a nighttime curfew beginning at 8 p.m. local time Friday and Saturday nights and continuing until 6 a.m. 

Here's the latest 👇
https://t.co/BWggxIfI0g

name: NPR
text:
Moscow has revised its coronavirus death toll to 1,561 — doubling the 636 fatalities initially reported amid criticism that Russia may have undercounted deaths from the disease. 
https://t.co/9k5pxvmBvW
